entry.title: Swift Basic: Only in Swift
entry.content:
Underscore: _

  • reference:
    • What is _: in Swift telling me?
    • Swift underscore(_)
    • Why do I need underscores in swift?

‚Äúignore this‚Äù
Underscroe is used to define the parameter is not named.
In for-loop, ‚Äúno index, just repeat.‚Äù

struct

entry.title: Swift Error Note
entry.content:
Type has no member

  • Search:
    • Swift - Type has no member
    • Type has no member? Swift

    This problem usually occurs in the module import error: wrong variable name, etc‚Ä¶

  • Cause: In my case, the problem is that the error is in the model class and I tried to use inside variable.

  • Result: Fixed the error in the model class.

Similar Error

  • Error msg:

    Value of type ‚ÄòUIViewController‚Äô has no member ‚ÄòvisibleViewContoller‚Äô

  • Search:
    • Receiving error: Value of type ‚ÄòUIViewController‚Äô has no member ‚ÄòopenViewControllerBasedOnIdentifier‚Äô
    • Value of type UIViewController has no member topViewController after Xcode 7 update

forUndefinedKey, NSUnknownKeyException

  • Error msg:

    setValue:forUndefinedKey:]: this class is not key value coding-compliant for the key f.‚Äù

  • Search:
    • ios NSUnknownKeyException
  • Cause: Referenced the deleted IBOulet in Storyboard.
  • Result: Implemented the IBOulet in source code.

Crash: NSInvalidArgumentException

Error message

  • Search:

  • Cause:
  • Result:
entry.summary: This note summarizes the errors that occurred during the development of Swift.

entry.title: [Swift Project] Smoking/Nonsmoking Area
entry.content:
1. Requirements

Project Objectives

Produce iOS apps that display üö¨smoking areas for smokers and üö≠ non-smoking areas for non-smokers in South Korea.

Specification

version 1.0.0

  • Mark smoking areas in the map. (YongSan-Gu)
  • Mark non-smoking areas in the map.
  • The map screen can be zoomed.
  • Can move to the current position on the map screen.

Next version

  • Precise way to mark ‚Äònear‚Äô positioin in non-smoking area. (current: same administrative & locality)
  • Mark other localities‚Äô smoking area API. (current: smoking area 1, non-smoking area: all South Korea except API error area.)
  • Show information of the selected area.
  • Optional: people density



2. Structure/Function

version 1.0.0

: one view, one controller, one model.

(1) View(main storyboard)

  • Apple MapView
  • two switch(smoking area, nonsmoking area on/off) with each label ‚Üí stack view
  • stepper(zoom)
  • button(current location)

(2) Main Controller

  • moveToCurrentLocation(): move to current location.
  • getCoordinateToAddress(): transfer coordinate(latitude & longitude) to Korean address.
  • addAnnotations(): add/remove multiple Annotations(markers) in the Apple MapView.
  • mapScaleStepper(): zoom in/out.
  • callJsonApi(): call public API in JSON format.
  • callXmlApi(): get public API in XML format.
  • smokingAreaSwitchAction(): smoking area annotations on/off.
  • nonsmokingAreaSwitchAction(): nonsmoking area annotations on/off.

(3) API Model

  • nonsmoking area API model
  • smoking area API model
  • address model

Next version

  • (main map) MVVC + (additional swipe window) MVC



3. Implementation: Focus on the Problem-Solving

: Among the implementations, parts that take a long time or still have a room for improvement are summarized with the source.

version 1.0.0

In version 1.0.0, there are main 4 features.

‚ûÄ Move to current location.
‚ûÅ Zoom in/out map.
‚ûÇ Display the non-smoking area data near the user on the map.
‚ûÉ Display the smoking area data of Yonsan-Gu on the map.

The codes below are the main functions needed to implement these four features.

Main problems

  • call XML/JSON API
  • synchronize with/without loop

Functions

‚ûÄ Move to current locations.

  • basic settings in viewDidLoad()
  • moveToCurrentLocation()

‚ûÅ Zoom map with Stepper

  • basic settings in viewDidLoad()
  • mapScaleStepper(_ sender: UIStepper)

‚ûÇ Add/Remove multiple Annotations in the map

: Area is the structure implemented in the Model.

  • Add
  • Remove

‚ûÉ Exchange Latitude & Longitude to Address

: This function is used in the nonsmokingAreaSwitchAction() function with the flow shown below.

Get current location‚Äôs latitude & longitude
‚Üí exchange latitude & longitude to Korean Address
‚Üí Extract the specific factor (ex. administrativeArea, locality of Address)
‚Üí get current location‚Äôs non-smoking areas‚Äô API using the factor

‚ûÑ API: XML format

: In this project, the Alamofire, CFRunLoop and completion is used to handle the XML type multiple API in the loop.

Calling API with NSXMLParserDelegate, handling its data and other ways to synchronize it will be delt with in another post.

‚ûÖ API: JSON format

Further Improvement

Refactoring

  • guard
  • error message (current: console)
  • Other ways to synchronize the API function.

Calling multiple APIs FAST without CPU, Momory overloading.

: In version 1.0.0, the application is quite slow especially when calling API.



4. Result

version 1.0.0

  • period: Aug 9, 2021 ~ Sep 5, 2021
entry.summary: Develop the iOS Application(Swift) that mark the Smoking/Non-smoking Areas in the map.

entry.title: [SpringBoot/Vue.js Project] Blog Implementation - Spring Boot
entry.content:
Backend Setting

application.properties

Config Package

MongoConfig Class

: Embedded Database Setting (Mongo DB)

OracleConfig Class

: External Database Setting (Oracle ATP DB)

WebConfig Class

: Fronted Connection Setting

ApiResponse Package

ApiResponse Abstract

Main API Packages

Item Class

: Model of the API, mostly from Oracle ATP Database. (Below is the partial of ArticleItem Class.)

Adapter Class

: Based in the @Builder of the Item Class, Adapter Class build the Response and Item(Model).

Repository Class

: Below is the Repository from Oracle ATP Database.

Controller Class

: URL Resolution for get, getAll, create, delete and update.

Service Class

: get, getAll, create, delete and update methods using Repository.

Response Class

: This class extends the ApiResponse Abtract from ApiResponse package.

Request Class
entry.summary: Blog Web Application implementation of Backend(SpringBoot).

entry.title: [SpringBoot/Vue.js Project] Blog
entry.content:
Develop an Web Application from start to finish! (with Oracle Cloud, Spring Boot, Vue.js)

1. Requirements

Project Objectives

  • Develop an Web Application that works as a personal Blog.

Specification

  • Article, Category CRUD.
  • Parent/Child relationships in categories.
  • Show projects by year.
  • Backend API -> Frontend.
  • Docker.

2. Structure

  • Database: Oracle ATP Database, (Partial) Mongo DB
  • Backend: SpringBoot
  • Frontend: Node.js, Vue.js

3. Function

Backend

: There are three APIs that hand over data from ATP Database to frontend.

  • Menu
    • One Menu is consisted of several(or one) Article.
    • Menu has Parent/Child relationship. (ex. Computer Science Menu - iOS/Android Menu)
  • Article
    • One Article is a page of writing.
  • Project
    • Project is the has information(ex. started date, ended date, project title‚Ä¶) about previously conducted projects.
    • Project API is mainly used on the homepage.

Frontend

: There are five main pages. (+ one sidebar)

  • Main features and design were implemented using Bootstrap-vue.
  • Axios used to call Springboot APIs.

4. Implementation

Backend

Implemented

  • Basic Settings
    • application.properties file: See Code‚Ä¶
  • Packages
    • 5 packages for basic functions have been developed.
      • Two packages are for setting: ApiResponse and Config.
      • The other packages are for API: ArticleItem, MenuItem and ProjectItem.

    • Except Config and ApiResponse package, one package consists of Item, Adapter, Controller, Repository, Request, Response and Service.

  • Config package
    This package is for the Database, Frontend and (+Security) connection settings.
    • Class: MongoConfig, OracleConfig, WebConfig
    • Detailed implementation of the Config package: See Code‚Ä¶
  • ApiReseponse package
    • This class is for the abstract ApiResponse.
    • API Response classes in other main three packages‚Äô API Response classes are inherited from this Abstract.
    • ApiReseponse Abstart: See Code..
  • ArticleItem, MenuItem, ProjectItem packages
    • One package consists of 6 classes and 1 interface: Item, Repository, Service, Adapter, Controller, Request, Response.
    • Item Class: Model class.
    • Adapter Class: ItemRespoense and Item methods exist to build object.
    • Repository Interface: Send queries to Database.
    • Service Class: Send Item to browser. (get, getAll, create, update, delete methods)
    • Controller Class: URL resolution.
    • Response and Request Class
    • See Code‚Ä¶

To Do / Ongoing

  • Membership related parts: Security package, SecurityConfig Class.
  • CI/CD with Docker!

Frontend

Implemented

  • Main three Pages implemented. Screenshots of the pages are at the below.
    • Home.vue: Projects and Articles.
    • Posts.vue: Entire articles with Menu(ex. Physics, Computer Science).
    • Aricle.vue: Descriptions.

To Do / Ongoing

  • Admin page for the Blog. (This shoud be linked with the articleEdit, menuEdit pages.)

5. Result

v1.0.0

  • Backend: Finish CRUD APIs for the Blog‚Äôs Article, Menu and Project.
  • Frontend: Development of pages for visitor completed.(include edit article/menu which is not below screenshots.)

The above page is the acutually working, but Oracle Cloud does not support free domain services in my region, I can‚Äôt attach Blog URL.
entry.summary: Develop an Web Application from start to finish! (with Oracle Cloud, Spring Boot, Vue.js)

entry.title: Web Application
entry.content:
Quantum information

Basic Concepts in Quantum Information, Steven M. Girvin‚Ä¶ ÏñëÏûê Ï†ïÎ≥¥Ïùò Í∏∞Î≥∏Ï†Å Í∞úÎÖê

In the last 25 years a new understanding has evolved of the role of information in quantum mechanics. ÏßÄÎÇú 25ÎÖÑÏùÄ ÏñëÏûê Ïó≠ÌïôÏóêÏÑú Ï†ïÎ≥¥Ïùò Ïó≠Ìï†Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Ïù¥Ìï¥Í¥ÄÍ≥ÑÍ∞Ä Î∞úÎã¨ÌïòÍ≤å ÎêòÏóàÎã§.

At the same time there has been tremendous progress in atomic/optical physics and condensed matter physics, and particularly at the interface between these two formerly distinct fields, in developing experimental systems whose quantum states are long-lived and which can be engineered to perform quantum information processing tasks ÎèôÏãúÏóê, ÏÑúÎ°ú ÌÅ∞ Íµ¨Î≥ÑÏù¥ ÏûàÎäî Î∂ÑÏïºÏù∏ ÏõêÏûê/Í¥ëÌïô Î¨ºÎ¶¨ÏôÄ ÏùëÏßë Î¨ºÏßà Î¨ºÎ¶¨ÌïôÏóêÏÑú Ïã§ÌóòÏ†Å Î¨ºÏßàÍ≥ÑÏóêÏÑú ÏñëÏûê ÏÉÅÌÉúÍ∞Ä ÏñëÏûê Ï†ïÎ≥¥ Ï†àÏ∞®Î•º ÏàòÌñâÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî Î∞úÏ†ÑÏùÑ ÎÇ®Í∏∞Î©∞, ÏóÑÏ≤≠ÎÇú ÏßÑÎ≥¥Í∞Ä ÏûàÏóàÎã§.

These lecture notes will present a brief introduction to the basic theoretical concepts behind this ‚Äòsecond quantum revolution.‚Äô Ïù¥ Í∞ïÏùò ÎÖ∏Ìä∏Îäî ‚ÄòÎëêÎ≤àÏß∏ ÏñëÏûê ÌòÅÎ™Ö‚ÄôÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Í∏∞Î≥∏Ï†Å Ïù¥Î°† Í∞úÎÖêÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏßßÏùÄ ÏÜåÍ∞úÏù¥Îã§.

These notes will also provide an introduction to ‚Äòcircuit QED.‚Äô Ïù¥ ÎÖ∏Ìä∏Îäî ÎòêÌïú ‚ÄòÌöåÎ°ú QED‚ÄôÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏÜåÍ∞úÎ•º Îã¥Í≥† ÏûàÎã§.

In addition to being a novel test bed for non-linear quantum optics of microwave electrical circuits which use superconducting qubits as artificial atoms, circuit QED offers an architecture for constructing quantum information processors. ÎßàÏù¥ÌÅ¨Î°úÌåå Ï†ÑÏûê ÌöåÎ°úÏùò ÎπÑÏÑ†Ìòï ÏñëÏûê Í¥ëÌïôÏóê ÎåÄÌïú novel test bed Î°úÏç®, ÌöåÎ°ú QEDÎäî ÏñëÏûê Ï†ïÎ≥¥ Ï†àÏ∞®Î•º ÏàòÌñâÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÍ≤å ÌïòÎäî Í∏∞Ï†ÄÎ•º Ï†úÍ≥µÌï¥Ï§ÄÎã§.

  1. INTRODUCTION and OVERVIEW ÏÜåÍ∞úÏôÄ Í∞úÏöî

Quantum mechanics is now more than 85 years old and is one of the most successful theories in all of physics. ÏñëÏûê Ïó≠ÌïôÏùÄ Ïù¥Ï†ú 85ÎÖÑÏù¥ ÎÑòÏóàÏúºÎ©∞, Ïù¥Ï†ú Î™®Îì† Î¨ºÎ¶¨Ìïô Ï§ë Í∞ÄÏû• ÏÑ±Í≥µÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ïù¥Î°† Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÏù¥Îã§.

With this theory we are able to make remarkably precise predictions of the outcome of experiments in the microscopic world of atoms, molecules, photons, and elementary particles. Ïù¥ Ïù¥Î°†ÏùÑ Î∞îÌÉïÏúºÎ°ú, Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî ÎØ∏ÏãúÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÏùò ÏõêÏûê, Î∂ÑÏûê, Í¥ëÏûê, Í∏∞Î≥∏ ÏûÖÏûêÎì§Ïùò Ïã§Ìóò Í≤∞Í≥ºÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Ï†ïÌôïÌïú ÏòàÏ∏°ÏùÑ Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§.

Yet despite this success, the subject remains shrouded in mystery because quantum phenomena are highly counter-intuitive to human beings whose intuition is built upon experience in the macroscopic world. Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú ÏÑ±Í≥µÏóêÎèÑ Î∂àÍµ¨ÌïòÍ≥†, ÏñëÏûê ÌòÑÏÉÅÏùÄ Í±∞ÏãúÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÏóêÏÑú Ïã§ÌóòÏùÑ ÌïòÎäî Ïù∏Í∞ÑÏùò ÏßÅÍ¥ÄÍ≥º ÏÉÅÎ∞òÎêòÍ∏∞Ïóê, Ïù¥ Ï£ºÏ†úÎäî Ïû•ÎßâÏóê ÎçÆÌòÄ ÏûàÏóàÎã§.

Indeed, the founders of the field struggled mightily to compre- hend it. Ïã§Î°ú, Ïù¥ Î∂ÑÏïºÏùò Ï∞ΩÏãúÏûêÎì§ÏùÄ Ïù¥Î•º Ïù¥Ìï¥ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ ÎßπÎ†¨ÌïòÍ≤å Ìà¨ÏüÅÌïòÏòÄÎã§.

Albert Einstein, who made truly fundamental contributions to the theory, never fully believed it Ïù¥ Ïù¥Î°†Ïùò ÏßÑÏ†ïÌïú Ï∞ΩÏãúÏûêÏù∏ ÏïåÎ≤ÑÌä∏ ÏïÑÏù∏ÏäàÌÉÄÏù∏Ï°∞Ï∞® Ïù¥Î•º ÏôÑÏ†ÑÌûà ÎØøÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÏòÄÎã§.

Ironically this was because he had the deepest understanding of the counter-intuitive predictions of the theory. ÏïÑÏù¥Îü¨ÎãàÌïòÍ≤åÎèÑ, Ïù¥Îäî Í∑∏Í∞Ä ÏñëÏûêÏó≠ÌïôÏùò ÏßÅÍ¥ÄÏ†ÅÏù¥ÏßÄ Î™ªÌïú ÏòàÏ∏°ÏùÑ ÏßÑÏ†ïÏúºÎ°ú Ïù¥Ìï¥ÌñàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥ÏóàÎã§.

In his remarkable ‚ÄòEPR‚Äô paper with Podolsky and Rosen,1 he famously proposed a thought experiment showing that quantum entanglement produced experimental outcomes that seemed to be obviously impossible. PodolskyÏôÄ RosenÍ≥ºÏùò ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ EPR ÎÖºÎ¨∏ÏóêÏÑú, Í∑∏Îäî ÏñëÏûê ÏñΩÌûòÏù¥ Î∂àÍ∞ÄÎä•Ìï¥ Î≥¥Ïù¥Îäî Í≤ÉÏúºÎ°ú ÌôïÏã§Ìïú Ïã§ÌóòÏ†Å Í≤∞Í≥ºÎ•º ÎèÑÏ∂úÌï¥ÎÇ∏Îã§Îäî Ï≤†Ï†ÄÌïú Ïã§ÌóòÏùÑ Î∞úÌëúÌïòÏòÄÎã§.

In an even greater irony, modern experiments based on John Bell‚Äôs analysis of the EPR ‚Äòparadox‚Äô now provide the best proof not only that quan- tum mechanics is correct, but that reality itself is simply not what we naively think it is.

Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ ÎçîÏö±Ïù¥ ÏïÑÏù¥Îü¨ÎãàÌïòÍ≤åÎèÑ, Ï°¥ Î≤®Ïùò EPR Ìå®Îü¨ÎèÖÏä§ Î∂ÑÏÑùÏóê Í∏∞Î∞òÌïú ÌòÑÎåÄ Ïã§ÌóòÎì§ÏùÄ ÏñëÏûê Ïó≠ÌïôÏù¥ Ïò¨Î∞îÎ•¥Î©∞, ÌòÑÏã§ÏùÄ Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÎßâÏó∞Ìûà ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥ ÏôîÎçò Í≤É Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏù¥ÎùºÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Ï¶ùÎ™ÖÌïòÏòÄÎã§.

In the last 25 years we have suddenly and quite unexpectedly come to a deeper understanding of the role of information in the quantum world. ÏßÄÎÇú 25ÎÖÑ ÎèôÏïà, ÏñëÏûê ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÏóêÏÑú Ï†ïÎ≥¥Ïùò Ï§ëÏöîÏÑ±ÏùÑ Í∞ëÏûëÏä§ÎüΩÍ≥† ÏòàÏ∏°ÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÍ≤å Ïù¥Ìï¥ÌïòÍ≤å ÎêòÏóàÎã§.

These ideas could very easily have been understood in 1930 because of the laws of quantum mechan- ics were known at the time. 1930ÎÖÑÏóêÎäî ÏñëÏûê Ïó≠ÌïôÏùò Î≤ïÏßÅÎì§Ïù¥ ÏïåÎ†§Ï†∏ ÏûàÏóàÍ∏∞Ïóê, Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú Ïù¥Î°†Îì§ÏùÄ Í∑∏ ÎãπÏãúÏóêÎäî ÏâΩÍ≤å Î∞õÏïÑÎì§Ïó¨Ï°åÎã§.

Yet, because of the counter-intuitive nature of these concepts, it would be nearly another 60 years before these further implications of the quantum laws came to be understood. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú Ïù¥Î°†Îì§Ïùò Î∞ò-ÏßÅÍ¥ÄÏ†Å ÏäµÏÑ± ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê, ÏñëÏûê Î≤ïÏπôÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÎòêÎã§Î•∏ Ìï®Ï∂ïÏ†Å ÏùòÎØ∏Í∞Ä Î∞õÏïÑÎì§Ïó¨ÏßÄÍ∏∞ÍπåÏßÄ Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÏ†ÅÏù∏ 60ÎÖÑÏù¥ Í±∏Î†∏Îã§.

We begin with a high-level ‚Äòexecutive summary‚Äô overview of these concepts and ideas which will then be developed in more detail in later sections. Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Ïù¥ Ïù¥Î°†Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú Í≥†ÎÇúÎèÑÏùò ‚ÄòÏã§Ïö©Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏïïÏ∂ïÌïú‚Äô Í∞úÏöîÎ•º ÌõëÏñ¥Î≥∏ Îí§Ïóê, ÏÉÅÏÑ∏Ìïú Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÑ ÏÇ¥Ìé¥Î≥º Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§.

From the earliest days of the quantum theory, the Heisenberg uncertainty prin- ciple taught us that certain physical quantities could never be known to arbitrary precision. ÏñëÏûê Ïù¥Î°†Ïùò Ï¥àÍ∏∞ÏóêÏÑúÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞, ÌïòÏù¥Ï††Î≤ÑÍ∑∏Ïùò Î∂àÌôïÏã§ÏÑ± ÏõêÎ¶¨Îäî ÌäπÏ†ï Î¨ºÎ¶¨Ï†Å ÏñëÏûêÎäî ÏûÑÏùòÏùò Ï†ïÌôïÏÑ±ÏùÑ Ï†àÎåÄÎ°ú Í∞ÄÏßà Ïàò ÏóÜÎã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Í∞ÄÎ•¥Ï≥ê Ï£ºÏóàÎã§.

This, combined with the genuine randomness of the outcome of certain measurements, seemed to indicate that somehow we were ‚Äòworse off‚Äô than we had been in the old world of classical physics. Ïù¥Îäî, ÌäπÏ†ï Ï∏°Ï†ï Í≤∞Í≥ºÏùò ÎπÑÏ†ïÌôïÏÑ±ÏùÄ Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Í≥†Ï†Ñ Ïó≠ÌïôÏóêÏÑú Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÏóàÎçò Í≤ÉÍ≥ºÎäî ‚ÄòÌõ®Ïî¨ Îçî Î©Ä‚Äô Îã§Îäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïó¨Ï£ºÏóàÎã§.

Recently however, we have come to un- derstand that quantum uncertainty, far from being a ‚Äòbug‚Äô, is actually a ‚Äòfeature‚Äô in the program of the universe. ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ÏµúÍ∑ºÏóêÎäî, Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî ÏñëÏûêÏ†Å Î∂àÌôïÏã§ÏÑ±Ïù¥, ‚ÄòÏò§Î•ò‚ÄôÎùºÍ∏∞Î≥¥Îã§Îäî Ïã§Ï†úÎ°úÎäî Ïö∞Ï£ºÏùò Í≥ÑÌöçÎêú ‚ÄòÌäπÏßï‚ÄôÏù¥ÎùºÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÑ Ïù¥Ìï¥ÌïòÏòÄÎã§.

Quantum uncertainty and its kin, entanglement, are actually powerful resources which we can use to great advantage to, encode, decode, transmit and process information in highly efficient ways that are impossible in the classical world. ÏñëÏûê Î∂àÌôïÏã§ÏÑ±Í≥º Í∑∏ ÎèôÎ•òÏù∏ ÏñëÏûê ÏñΩÌûòÏùÄ Ïù¥Ï†ÑÏùò Í≥†Ï†Ñ Ïó≠ÌïôÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÌïòÏßÄ Î™ªÌïòÏòÄÎçò Î∞©ÏãùÏúºÎ°ú, Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏïîÌò∏Ìôî,Î≥µÌò∏Ìôî, Ï†ÑÏÜ°, Ï≤òÎ¶¨ÌïòÎäî Îç∞Ïóê Í∑πÎèÑÎ°ú Ìö®Ïú®Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î∞©Î≤ïÏù¥ÏóàÎã§.

In addition to being a profound advance in our understanding of quantum mechanics, these revolutionary ideas have spurred development of a new kind of quantum engineering whose goal is to develop working quantum ‚Äòmachines.‚Äô2 Ïù¥ ÎøêÎßå ÏïÑÎãàÎùº ÏñëÏûê Ïó≠ÌïôÏùò ÍπäÏùÄ Ïù¥Ìï¥Î•º ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏïûÏÑúÏÑú, Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú ÌòÅÎ™ÖÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÏïÑÏù¥ÎîîÏñ¥Îì§ÏùÄ Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú ÎèôÏûëÌïòÎäî ÏñëÏûê ‚ÄòÍ∏∞Í≥Ñ‚ÄôÎì§ÏùÑ Í∞úÎ∞úÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥ Î™©ÌëúÏù∏ ÏñëÏûê ÏóîÏßÄÎãàÏñ¥ÎßÅÏùò Í∞úÎ∞úÏóê Î∞ïÏ∞®Î•º Í∞ÄÌïòÏòÄÎã§.

The new ideas that have been developed also have profound applications for pre- cision measurements and atomic clocks. Í∞úÎ∞úÎêú ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Ïù¥Î°†ÎèÑ Ïó≠Ïãú ÏõêÏûê ÏãúÍ≥ÑÏùò Ï†ïÌôïÌïú Ï∏°ÎüâÏùÑ ÏúÑÌïú Ïã¨ÎèÑ ÍπäÏùÄ ÏùëÏö©Ïù¥ÏóàÎã§.

For example, ordinary atomic clocks keep track of time by following the evolution of product states of N spins, each precessing at frequency Œ©0: |Œ®(t)‚ü© = [|0‚ü© + e‚àíiŒ©0 t |1‚ü©] ‚äó [|0‚ü© + e‚àíiŒ©0 t |1‚ü©] ‚äó . . . ‚äó [|0‚ü© + e‚àíiŒ©0 t |1‚ü©]. ( ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥ÏÑú, Í∏∞Ï°¥Ïùò ÏõêÏûê ÏãúÍ≥ÑÎäî Œ©0 frequency, N Ïä§ÌïÄ ÏÉÅÌÉú Î¨ºÏßàÏùò ÏßÑÌôîÎäî ÏïÑÎûòÏôÄ Í∞ôÏù¥ ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ Îî∞Îùº ÌùòÎü¨Í∞ÑÎã§:

By using maximally entangled states of the form |Œ®(t)‚ü© = [|0000 . . . 0‚ü© + e‚àíiN Œ©0 t |1111 . . . 1‚ü©] (2) one gets a clock which runs N times faster and therefore gains a factor of ‚àöN in precision. ÏµúÎåÄÌïúÏúºÎ°ú ÏñΩÌûå ÏÉÅÎåÄÏù∏ (2)Îäî NÎ∞∞ Îπ†Î•∏ ÏãúÍ≥ÑÎ•º Í∞ÄÏßÄÎ©∞, Î£®Ìä∏ N Ìå©ÌÑ∞Ïùò Ï†ïÌôïÎèÑÎ•º Í∞ÄÏßÑÎã§.

3

Develop an Web Application from start to finish! (with Oracle Cloud, Spring Boot, Vue.js)

1. Requirements

Project Objectives

  • Develop an Web Application that works as a personal Blog.

Specification

  • Article, Category CRUD.
  • Parent/Child relationships in categories.
  • Show projects by year.
  • Backend API -> Frontend.
  • Docker.

2. Structure

  • Database: Oracle ATP Database, (Partial) Mongo DB
  • Backend: SpringBoot
  • Frontend: Node.js, Vue.js

3. Function

Backend

: There are three APIs that hand over data from ATP Database to frontend.

  • Menu
    • One Menu is consisted of several(or one) Article.
    • Menu has Parent/Child relationship. (ex. Computer Science Menu - iOS/Android Menu)
  • Article
    • One Article is a page of writing.
  • Project
    • Project is the has information(ex. started date, ended date, project title‚Ä¶) about previously conducted projects.
    • Project API is mainly used on the homepage.

Frontend

: There are five main pages. (+ one sidebar)

  • Main features and design were implemented using Bootstrap-vue.
  • Axios used to call Springboot APIs.

4. Implementation

Backend

Implemented

  • Basic Settings
    • application.properties file: See Code‚Ä¶
  • Packages
    • 5 packages for basic functions have been developed.
      • Two packages are for setting: ApiResponse and Config.
      • The other packages are for API: ArticleItem, MenuItem and ProjectItem.

    • Except Config and ApiResponse package, one package consists of Item, Adapter, Controller, Repository, Request, Response and Service.

  • Config package
    This package is for the Database, Frontend and (+Security) connection settings.
    • Class: MongoConfig, OracleConfig, WebConfig
    • Detailed implementation of the Config package: See Code‚Ä¶
  • ApiReseponse package
    • This class is for the abstract ApiResponse.
    • API Response classes in other main three packages‚Äô API Response classes are inherited from this Abstract.
    • ApiReseponse Abstart: See Code..
  • ArticleItem, MenuItem, ProjectItem packages
    • One package consists of 6 classes and 1 interface: Item, Repository, Service, Adapter, Controller, Request, Response.
    • Item Class: Model class.
    • Adapter Class: ItemRespoense and Item methods exist to build object.
    • Repository Interface: Send queries to Database.
    • Service Class: Send Item to browser. (get, getAll, create, update, delete methods)
    • Controller Class: URL resolution.
    • Response and Request Class
    • See Code‚Ä¶

To Do / Ongoing

  • Membership related parts: Security package, SecurityConfig Class.
  • CI/CD with Docker!

Frontend

Implemented

  • Main three Pages implemented. Screenshots of the pages are at the below.
    • Home.vue: Projects and Articles.
    • Posts.vue: Entire articles with Menu(ex. Physics, Computer Science).
    • Aricle.vue: Descriptions.

To Do / Ongoing

  • Admin page for the Blog. (This shoud be linked with the articleEdit, menuEdit pages.)

5. Result

v1.0.0

  • Backend: Finish CRUD APIs for the Blog‚Äôs Article, Menu and Project.
  • Frontend: Development of pages for visitor completed.(include edit article/menu which is not below screenshots.)

The above page is the acutually working, but Oracle Cloud does not support free domain services in my region, I can‚Äôt attach Blog URL.

entry.title: Swift Basic
entry.content:
1. Swift Collection Data Structure

Array

  • Initialization
  • Get size
  • Access
  • Append/Insert
  • Remove/Pop/Drop
  • Modify
  • Sort/Sorted
  • Min/Max
  • Reverse

String/Character

  • Access String‚Äôs Character
  • Append a Character to a String
    • Convert a Character to a String
  • Using insert()

Dictionary

  • Initialization
  • Sort

: The two above return an Array. So, if you want to access the values of sortedByKey, try this

2. Control Flow

For

3. Operator

Unsupported Operator

  • ++, --
  • &&

4. Optional

Converting Optional

  • Optional Binding
  • Optional Chaining (+ Optional Binding)
  • Forced Unwrapping
    This is usually used when class initialization or implicitly unwrapped optionals.
  • Nil-Coalescing Operator

Referece

  • Data Structure
    • Swift array blog
    • Swift for blog
    • Swift stride blog
    • Swift data structure
    • Swift3 Array Usage
    • Swift String and Characters
    • How to append a character to a string in Swift?
    • Dictionary Sort
    • Sort Dictionary by Key(Example)
  • Optional
    • Warning Converting Optional to String
    • What is Optional
entry.summary: Swift Data Structure, Operator, Control Flow.

entry.title: Webtoon Application(iOS)
entry.content:
Webtoon Market Research

reference: Webtoon market share (Android)

  • Naver Webtoon (5,521,674 users)
  • KakaoPage (2,411,481 users)

Common Features

  • Bottom Navigation Bar
  • Main Page: Weekly Webtoons (+ Novels‚Ä¶)
  • My Page: Webtoons I‚Äôve seen.
  • View More: Setting, Cookie/Cash, Notice‚Ä¶

Naver Webtoon vs KakaoPage

iOS Application Development

Interface: Sketch

  • reference: https://www.sketch.com/docs/
  • blogs
    • GUI Introduction Blog
    • Sketch Blog - Start!

###
entry.summary: Based on existing webtoons applications, produce an iOS sample webtoon application as a test.
